This is a lie, Harvey.Â  The Christian Scientists have website of cures following prayers, but they are meaningless.Â  If your god was of value in healing the sick doctors would use it first, your god would be the go-to guy.Â  But, that's not what's seen.Â  In circumstances like you outlined here, the Christianity lie-machine goes into full gullibility gear and Christians just accept each other's tales of miracles and answered prayers.Â  These imagined miracles derive from ignorance, credulity, and superstition-thick social circumstances.Â  If your god was actually working, Harvey, the numbers would show that praying leads begets miracles more often than not praying, but that's not what is seen.Â  Income begets miracles.Â  Education begets miracles.Â  Praying does nothing. Some fundamentalist Christian friends recently had a nephew die young of cancer.Â  The doctors predicted him to live six months; he died in three weeks.Â  That was no miracle, but they would have claimed a miracle if he had lived six months after a three-week-to-live prediction.Â  You Christians are just lying to each other, Harvey. And, do you really think you can say "I've seen him raise the dead" and get away with it.Â  Harvey, you lie to prop up your Christian social superstitions.Â  You lie more than some Christians and less than others.Â  But, the lying costs us all dearly.Â  People, like you, who cannot accept and deal with the world as it is hinder humanity's capacity to make the world a better place.Â  Pathological hope is a defect, not a virtue.Â  Allowing your ignorance to be the basis for something you so desperately want, miracles, means you have reserved a special place in your mind for ignorance.Â  It is ignorance which makes the miracle-making in your Christian social club possible.Â  Take away the ignorance and the miracles and answered prayers go right along with it. If you claims were true, we would all be able to see it.Â  We scientists would be right their identifying how to best structure your prayers for optimum affect.Â  As yet, however, no prayer has ever been answered supernaturally, so there is nothing to study.
